title: I took out a loan with the company Loanme. I am unable to pay it back, can they garnish my wages. Im an independant contractor?
question: Things changed drastically for me financially and I’m unable to repay this loan. I issued a stop payment with my bank and am canceling my debit card to prevent payments, I am considering bankruptcy but I recall checking something on the loan application that said something about me having no intent to file bankruptcy in the next 12 months. I had no intent when I checked the box. I’m worried I will get my wages garnished, but I’m an independant contractor. I work for Uber/Lyft, and a few others. They have a bank statement that shows my deposits and from which companies. Can they garnish my wages from these companies? Will the bankruptcy option help me?
answers:
There is a way to go after your independent contractor income, I've only seen it once, but technically it is possible, it's not a wage garnishment, per se.

Will LoanMe take that route? Hard to say. I just recently talked to an individual with a personal loan from that organization, reviewed the contract that was signed, absolutely terms, 85%+ interest rates for one loan, 135% on another. Highway robbery here.

Whether a debt settlement or bankruptcy is a good route depends on more facts about your situation. It doesn't hurt to extent an offer of settlement. However, many people who take out these, IMO "debt trap" loans, do so because they are desperate for funds and can't borrow from family or friends nor can they liquidate some assets to come up with some money to make a settlement offer. But that is not always the case.

Speak to an attorney. We offer free consults. They'll want to among other things calculate your Debt to Income Ratio and your Disposable Income to determine best course of action.

Filing a bankruptcy can be an easy fix to this and preventative measure. Bankruptcy prohibits most of your creditors from garnishing your wages (if you were employed) and/or levying your bank accounts. A creditor typically first needs a judgment before they can garnish or levy. Bankruptcy can wipe away your debts and give you a fresh start. I suggest consulting with a local bankruptcy attorney.

Loanme would have to sue you and get a judgment before they try to collect from you. Since you are not a W-2 employee they cannot force you to garnish your own wages but they can levy your bank account once they have a judgment against you. They must file and serve a lawsuit first. If that happens you should consult with a bankruptcy or debt relief attorney for assistance. The loan could be discharged in bankruptcy despite what the underlying contract says about not filing for 12 months.
You don’t have wages. They can grab payment made to you, but it’s harder than garnishment.

You can file bankruptcy and get ride of this debt as it is your right to do so. They could file a lawsuit and try to collect but a bankruptcy would prevent that. Consult with a San Diego attorney as soon as possible
